evidence.text: This civil rights class action is brought pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 1983 on behalf of all foster children who are or will be in the legal custody of DHS.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief and Request for Class Action

evidence.text: Whether DHS's policies and practices violate Plaintiff Children's substantive due process rights to be reasonably free from harm and imminent risk of harm while in state custody, guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief and Request for Class Action

add_extracted.value: Fourteenth Amendment

evidence.text: In 2002, 1.62% of Oklahoma foster care children were abused or neglected, almost three times greater than the federal benchmark of 0.57% for children in foster care; in 2003, the Oklahoma rate rose to 1.88%, or 3.3 times the federal benchmark.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief and Request for Class Action

add_extracted.value: Oklahoma's rate of abuse or neglect of foster children in state custody consistently exceeded federal benchmarks, with rates of 1.62% (2002) and 1.88% (2003) compared to federal benchmarks of 0.57%.

evidence.text: D.G. entered DHS custody in Oklahoma County in September of 2007... DHS kept D.G. languishing in the shelter for at least twenty-two days. ... C.S. entered DHS custody in Tulsa County in February of 2007... DHS placed C.S. in the overcrowded and poorly supervised 'Little House' for babies at the Laura Dester Emergency Shelter.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief and Request for Class Action

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff Children D.G., C.S., J.B., A.P., J.A., J.P., R.J., and G.C. have experienced unsafe placements, frequent moves, and inadequate monitoring by DHS, resulting in physical and psychological harm.

evidence.text: The foster care maintenance payments in Oklahoma are not based on a methodology reflecting the actual and reasonable payments... Oklahoma's foster care maintenance payments would need to be increased by over 50% before they could begin to cover the reasonable and actual costs of raising a child.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief and Request for Class Action

add_extracted.value: DHS's failure to provide adequate foster care maintenance payments has contributed to a shortage of foster homes and placement of children in emergency shelters for extended periods.

evidence.text: DHS routinely fails to adequately screen and investigate potential foster parents and their homes before approving them for the placement of children in DHS custody... DHS also fails to close foster homes promptly - or close them at all - where children in DHS custody have been subjected to abuse or neglect.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief and Request for Class Action

add_extracted.value: DHS routinely fails to adequately screen foster homes and monitor placements, resulting in confirmed abuse and neglect of children in state custody.
